The wooden rod is released from rest and falls freely under gravity.
The height of the cylinder is 5 m, and the total distance the rod needs to fall to pass through the cylinder is 20 m.
Using the equation of motion \( s = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \), we can find the time \( t \) it takes for the rod to fall a certain distance.
The time \( t_1 \) to pass through the upper end \( A \) of the cylinder can be calculated by considering the distance the rod has fallen when the upper end reaches the top of the cylinder.
The time \( t_2 \) to pass through the lower end \( B \) of the cylinder can be calculated by considering the distance the rod has fallen when the lower end reaches the bottom of the cylinder.
The difference between \( t_2 \) and \( t_1 \) gives the time \( t_1 \) it takes for the wooden rod to pass through the upper end \( A \) of the cylinder.
